qas.question: How did the Arab world react to news of the nationalization of the Suez Canal?
What nation's shipping was forbidden from using the Suez Canal?
What US ambassador spoke about the widespread support for Nasser's nationalization of the canal?
Where was Nasser believed to be a spokesman for the poor and oppressed?

answers.text: not only in Egypt, but all over the Third World

context: The nationalization announcement was greeted very emotionally by the audience and, throughout the Arab world, thousands entered the streets shouting slogans of <a0_0>support<a0_0/>. US ambassador <a2_0>Henry A. Byroade<a2_0/> stated, "I cannot overemphasize [the] popularity of the Canal Company nationalization within Egypt, even among Nasser's enemies." Egyptian political scientist Mahmoud Hamad wrote that, prior to 1956, Nasser had consolidated control over Egypt's military and civilian bureaucracies, but it was only after the canal's nationalization that he gained near-total popular legitimacy and firmly established himself as the "charismatic leader" and "spokesman for the masses <a3_0>not only in Egypt, but all over the Third World<a3_0/>". According to Aburish, this was Nasser's largest pan-Arab triumph at the time and "soon his pictures were to be found in the tents of Yemen, the souks of Marrakesh, and the posh villas of Syria". The official reason given for the nationalization was that funds from the canal would be used for the construction of the dam in Aswan. That same day, Egypt closed the canal to <a1_0>Israeli<a1_0/> shipping.
